name: Xi Wangmu
subtitle: Queen Mother of the West
description: Xi Wangmu is one of the oldest and most powerful goddesses in Chinese mythology, the immortal Queen who rules from her paradise on Mount Kunlun. Guardian of the Peaches of Immortality and keeper of the elixir of eternal life, she presides over female immortals and represents the ultimate yin principle of the cosmos.
titles: Golden Mother of the Jade Pool (Áë∂Ê±†ÈáëÊØç)
Primordial Ruler of the Western Heaven

mythology_content.overview: Xi Wangmu is one of the oldest deities in Chinese religion, appearing in texts from the Shang dynasty oracle bones through to contemporary worship. Her mythology evolved dramatically over millennia, from a fearsome goddess of plague and punishment to the benevolent Queen of Immortality.

peachesOfImmortality.description: Xi Wangmu's most famous treasure is her garden of immortal peaches on Mount Kunlun.

threeTypes.effect: Grant eternal life equal to heaven and earth

peachesOfImmortality.peachBanquet: Every eon, Xi Wangmu hosts the Peach Banquet (Ëü†Ê°É‰ºö), inviting all gods and immortals to feast on the ripened peaches. This is the most prestigious event in the celestial calendar.

mountKunlun.description: Xi Wangmu's realm is the legendary Mount Kunlun (ÊòÜ‰ªëÂ±±), described as the axis mundi connecting earth and heaven.
features: The cosmic mountain at the center/west of the world, beyond mortal reach
Jade Palace by the Jade Pool (Áë∂Ê±†)
Rivers of immortality, gardens of jade trees, halls of crystal

keyMyths.title: Ancient Origins
keyMyths.description: In the earliest texts (Shanhaijing/Classic of Mountains and Seas), Xi Wangmu appears as a fearsome goddess with a human face, leopard's tail, and tiger's teeth. She dwells in a cave on Jade Mountain, controlling plague, punishment, and the five calamities.

keyMyths.title: Meeting King Mu of Zhou
keyMyths.description: Emperor Mu of Zhou (c. 10th century BCE) journeyed west in his chariot drawn by eight magical horses. He reached Mount Kunlun and was received by Xi Wangmu. They exchanged poems and gifts, and she hosted a banquet by the Jade Pool.

keyMyths.title: Chang'e and the Moon
keyMyths.description: Xi Wangmu gave the elixir of immortality to the hero Houyi as a reward for shooting down nine of the ten suns. His wife Chang'e drank the elixir and floated to the moon, where she still dwells.

keyMyths.title: Journey to the West
keyMyths.description: Xi Wangmu's Peach Banquet is disrupted when Sun Wukong, appointed guardian of the orchard, eats all the ripened peaches, drinks the immortal wine, and consumes Laozi's pills of immortality.

keyMyths.title: The Weaver Girl (Zhinu)
keyMyths.description: In some versions of the Cowherd and Weaver Girl legend, Xi Wangmu separated the lovers by creating the Milky Way with her jade hairpin, allowing them to meet only once per year on Qixi.

yinPrinciple: Supreme embodiment of cosmic yin energy
Represents the west, autumn, metal element
Balances the yang of the Jade Emperor or Dong Wanggong
Controls death and rebirth, the cycle of transformation
motherOfImmortals: All female immortals are under her authority
Grants immortality through her peaches and elixirs
Represents the goal of Daoist cultivation

archetype.description: Xi Wangmu embodies the Great Goddess archetype - primordial feminine power, keeper of life and death, guardian of immortality, dwelling in the sacred mountain paradise.

sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Xi Wangmu is one of the oldest and most powerful goddesses in Chinese mythology, the immortal Queen who rules from her paradise on Mount Kunlun. Guardian of the Peaches of Immortality and keeper of the elixir of eternal life, she presides over female immortals and represents the ultimate yin principle of the cosmos.
